curriculumTitle: Zoofari Investigations: Ethology, Conservation, and Habitat Engineering (Modular Edition)
overview: This refined STEM curriculum adapts the scientific study of wildlife into highly flexible 30-minute modules. It transforms a visit to Fossil Rim Wildlife Center into a rigorous scientific field study suitable for UB and UBMS grants. To accommodate tight schedules and precise compliance reporting, the Field Study component has been segmented into specific 30-minute academic data-collection modules.
prerequisites: Completion of 9th Grade Biology (recommended); Understanding of the Scientific Method; Basic Arithmetic (Mean, Median, Mode).

fieldTrips.name: Fossil Rim Wildlife Center
fieldTrips.location: Glen Rose, TX (Accessible from Tarrant/Johnson Counties via US-67)
fieldTrips.description: A 1,800-acre wildlife preserve featuring a drive-through safari experience where students can observe herds of exotic and endangered species in semi-natural habitats.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Provides the 'Living Laboratory' required for the data collection modules. Students observe herd dynamics and enclosure engineering in a setting that mimics natural environments.

activities.title: Module 1.1: Introduction to Ethology
activities.description: Part A of the foundational session. Students define Ethology and categorize behaviors as innate or learned.
learningObjectives: Define Ethology as a distinct scientific discipline.
Differentiate between Innate (instinctive) and Learned behaviors.
Identify three careers related to animal science.
teks: Biology 112.34 (c)(12)(A): Interpret relationships including predation, parasitism, competition, commensalism, and mutualism.
texasStemStandards: STEM Content Standard 3.A: Application of scientific inquiry.

detailed: Introduce 'Ethology' (study of animal behavior) vs. 'Training'.
Activity: List behaviors on board (e.g., breathing, shaking hands). Have students sort them into Innate vs. Learned.
Briefly introduce the career pathway of an Ethologist.
Write the definition of Ethology.
Classify the list of behaviors provided by the instructor.
Identify one behavior your pet does that is innate, and one that is learned.

heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b)(1): Academic instruction in science.

activities.title: Module 1.2: Objectivity & Anthropomorphism
activities.description: Part B of the foundational session. Students learn to eliminate subjective language from observation.
learningObjectives: Define Anthropomorphism.
Rewrite subjective descriptions into objective data points.
teks: Biology 112.34 (c)(2)(F): Collect and organize qualitative and quantitative data.

detailed: Play a 'funny' animal video. Ask students what the animal feels.
Explain Anthropomorphism (projecting human traits) and why it invalidates research.
Have students rewrite their initial description using only physical movements (e.g., 'showing teeth' instead of 'smiling').
Watch the clip. Write what the animal is 'feeling'.
After the lecture, cross out emotion words.
Rewrite the description focusing only on muscle movements and posture.

trioCompliance.justification: Ensures academic rigor in observation skills.

activities.title: Module 2.1: Sampling Methodologies
activities.description: Part A of Methodologies. Students differentiate between Focal and Scan sampling techniques.
learningObjectives: Distinguish between Focal Sampling (individual) and Scan Sampling (group).
Determine which method is best for specific research questions.
teks: Biology 112.34 (c)(2)(G): Analyze, evaluate, make inferences, and predict trends from data.
texasStemStandards: STEM Career Standard 5.B: Explore STEM careers.

detailed: Explain that Focal is watching one subject, Scan is taking a snapshot of a group.
Simulation: Have 3 students act out actions. Have the class try to record all 3 (Scan) vs just 1 (Focal).
Create a T-Chart comparing Focal and Scan sampling.
During the simulation, attempt to record data based on the method assigned to your row.

activities.title: Module 2.2: Ethogram & Hypothesis
activities.description: Part B of Methodologies. Students select their species, create the data tool (Ethogram), and write a hypothesis.
learningObjectives: Create a standardized Ethogram with behavior codes (e.g., F=Foraging).
Formulate a null and alternative hypothesis.

detailed: Assign teams (e.g., Team Rhino).
Guide students to agree on 5 codes (e.g., R=Resting). Emphasize inter-observer reliability.
Check that every student has a written hypothesis: 'If [condition], then [behavior] because [reason].'
Look up your animal. What do they do most?
Create a code list. Everyone on the team must agree on the codes.
Write your prediction for the field trip.

activities.title: Module 3.1: Field Lab - Calibration & Safety
activities.description: The first 30-minute segment of the field study. Students perform on-site safety checks and calibrate their timing devices for inter-observer reliability.
learningObjectives: Demonstrate compliance with field safety protocols.
Synchronize timing devices to within 1 second of accuracy.
Conduct a test observation on a common species (e.g., Emu) to ensure code agreement.
teks: Biology 112.34 (c)(1)(A): Demonstrate safe practices during field and laboratory investigations.
texasStemStandards: STEM Content Standard 4.A: Real-world safety and protocol.

detailed: Conduct a head-count and safety briefing upon arrival at Fossil Rim.
Have all students start stopwatches simultaneously to check for drift.
Point out the first animal seen and ask all students to code it simultaneously to check for agreement.
Listen to the safety briefing regarding bus windows and feeding rules.
Synchronize your watch with the lead researcher (teacher).
Write down the behavior code for the first animal identified.

trioCompliance.justification: Required safety and calibration for scientific data collection.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b)(10): Activities for limited English proficiency (hands-on).

activities.title: Module 3.2: Field Lab - Ruminant Herd Scan
activities.description: The second 30-minute segment. Students apply Scan Sampling methodology to herd animals (Wildebeest/Gazelle) in the Grazing Zone.
learningObjectives: Execute Scan Sampling on a herd greater than 10 individuals.
Record interval data every 60 seconds for 20 minutes.
Identify herd hierarchy behaviors.
teks: Env Systems 112.37 (c)(7)(D): Analyze flow of energy (grazing).

detailed: Direct student attention to a herd (e.g., Wildebeest).
Call 'Mark' every 60 seconds.
Ensure students are counting the number of individuals engaging in specific behaviors (Scan).

brief: Do not focus on one animal.
detailed: Look at the whole group.
At the 'Mark' signal, write how many animals are resting vs. eating.
Repeat until the session ends.

edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.432: Field trips for educational purposes.

activities.title: Module 3.3: Field Lab - Mega-Vertebrate Focal Study
activities.description: The third 30-minute segment. Students switch to Focal Sampling to observe individual mega-fauna (Rhino or Giraffe).
learningObjectives: Execute Focal Sampling on a single subject.
Record continuous behavior codes.
Note specific interactions with the environment.
teks: Biology 112.34 (c)(11)(B): Homeostasis and response to environment.

detailed: Assign specific animals to student pairs (e.g., 'You watch the giraffe with the dark spots').
Ensure students are recording behavior changes instantly (Continuous) or at intervals (Instantaneous).
Verify codes match the Ethogram created in Module 2.2.
Lock eyes on your specific animal.
Every time the timer beeps, record exactly what THAT animal is doing.
Do not switch animals even if another one does something interesting.

activities.title: Module 3.4: Field Lab - Habitat Engineering Audit
activities.description: The final 30-minute segment of the field study. Students shift focus from animals to infrastructure, analyzing fences, gates, and enrichment devices.
learningObjectives: Identify three types of containment barriers (e.g., moat, electric fence, mesh).
Sketch the mechanics of a feeding station or gate.
Evaluate the effectiveness of environmental enrichment.

detailed: Point out the differences in fencing for Rhinos (cable) vs. Cheetahs (chain link).
Discuss why different animals require different engineering solutions.
Have students sketch a gate or feeder mechanism for Module 5.
Look at how the animals are kept in.
Draw a diagram of the fence or gate latch.
Note what materials are used (wood, metal, wire).

trioCompliance.justification: Engineering component of the field study.

activities.title: Module 4.1: Data Calculation
activities.description: Part A of Data Analysis. Students convert raw tally marks from the field trip into usable percentages.
learningObjectives: Convert raw frequency counts into percentages.
Calculate Mean and Mode for specific behaviors.
teks: Math 111.47 (c)(2): Analyze data sets using summaries.
texasStemStandards: STEM Content Standard 4.B: Application of math.

detailed: Have students sum their tally marks.
Teach: (Count / Total Observations) * 100 = Percentage.
Check student work to ensure percentages sum to 100%.
Count how many times you saw 'Resting'.
Divide by total minutes observed.
Multiply by 100 to get the percentage.

activities.title: Module 4.2: Data Visualization
activities.description: Part B of Data Analysis. Students use software to create Activity Budget charts.
learningObjectives: Create Pie Charts and Bar Graphs.
Interpret the visual data to accept or reject the hypothesis.
texasStemStandards: STEM Content Standard 4.B: Application of math.

detailed: Guide students to input their calculated percentages into columns.
Show how to insert a Pie Chart.
Ask: 'Does this chart look like a healthy animal?'
Input your data into the spreadsheet.
Generate a Pie Chart titled 'Activity Budget'.
Compare the chart to your original prediction.

activities.title: Module 5.1: Engineering - Problem Identification
activities.description: Part A of Engineering Challenge. Students interpret their graphs to identify a biological problem (e.g., boredom, lack of exercise).
learningObjectives: Apply the 'Ask' phase of the Engineering Design Process.
Correlate data (high pacing) with biological issues (stress).
texasStemStandards: STEM Culture Standard 6.A: Animal welfare ethics.

detailed: Ask: 'If the animal paced 40% of the time, what does that mean?'
Explain 'Stereotypic Behavior' (stress responses).
Have students write a Problem Statement: 'The rhino needs more foraging time to reduce pacing.'
Look at your chart. Is the animal too sedentary? Pacing too much?
Write a statement defining the problem you want to solve.

activities.title: Module 5.2: Engineering - Prototyping
activities.description: Part B of Engineering Challenge. Students sketch and build a physical model of an enrichment device.
learningObjectives: Apply 'Imagine' and 'Create' phases of Engineering Design.
Build a scale model using craft materials.
teks: Physics 112.39 (c)(3)(F): Express relationships among physical variables.

detailed: Provide materials. Challenge: 'Build a device to solve the problem defined in Mod 5.1'.
Ensure designs are safe for animals (no sharp edges in concept).
Encourage rapid prototyping.
Sketch a new feeder or climbing structure.
Build a small model using cardboard and tape.
Make sure it addresses the specific behavior problem.

activities.title: Module 5.3: Engineering - Presentation
activities.description: Part C of Engineering Challenge. Students pitch their solutions to a mock grant committee.
learningObjectives: Justify design decisions using data.
Present technical information to an audience.

detailed: Act as the Zoo Director/Grant Officer.
Have groups present for 2-3 minutes.
Ask: 'How does this device prove it will reduce the pacing behavior you observed?'
Explain your problem (Data).
Explain your solution (Model).
Explain why it works (Biology).
